data.title: autoSave and trimTrailingWhitespace incompatible

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.13.1
- OS Version: MacOS Sierra 10.12.6

Steps to Reproduce:
Use the following settings
```bash
"files.autoSave": "afterDelay",
"files.autoSaveDelay": 1000,
"files.trimTrailingWhitespace" :true
```

I would expect that `trimTrailingWhitespace` removes the trailing whitespaces every time `autoSave` is triggered. This is unfortunately not the case. The combination `autoSave` with `trimTrailingWhitespace` does not work. Removing `autoSave` and saving the file manually works.

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: Unexpected behavior of conditional break
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.16.0-insider
- OS Version: Windows 8.1 64-bit

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create a Python for loop using enumerate():
```
values = ['Testing1', 'Testing2', 'Testing3']
for index, value in enumerate(values):
    test = index
    print(test, value)
```
2. Create a conditional break in line after `for index...` with value `index = 1`. Expected behavior is to break when the value of `index` is equal to 1. It breaks/stops at `index = 0`

data.title: Typescript Intelligence Bug: different behaviors on  interface implementation.
focus opened file when opened from Explorer Side Bar
data.body:
Steps to Reproduce:

1. Ctrl+Shift+E to open Explorer Side Bar
2. Click on a file in the Explorer Side Bar, thus opening it or a preview of it
3. press some letter keys. the typed keys do not appear in the opened file, because the opened file isn't focused
4. Ctrl+1 to focus the file, and then type again; now text will appear.

Expected behavior: file should be focused without needing Ctrl+1

data.title: Telemetry for installing recommended extensions
data.body:
This PR adds an event to track if the "Install" button on a recommended extension is clicked by the user.

I am piggy backing on the `Extension`s payload. Couldn't find any other way to pass the information that the extension is recommended all the way to `ExtensionAction.ts`. Any suggestions?

data.title: Telemetry for installing recommended extensions
data.body:
This PR adds an event to track if the "Install" button on a recommended extension is clicked by the user.

I am piggy backing on the `Extension`s payload. Couldn't find any other way to pass the information that the extension is recommended all the way to `ExtensionAction.ts`. Suggestions are welcome.

In the future we will properties to denote the source of the recommendation as well.

cc @kieferrm

data.title: Telemetry for Ext recommendations pop ups
data.body:
This PR adds 2 events to track the user's reactions to the Extension Recommendation and Workspace Extension Recommendation pop ups

cc @kieferrm

data.title: Show keybinding conflicts for `Ctrl+Space` should not include `Ctrl+Backspace`
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.16.0-insider (0626479859787fa87c7c57ba19195b939050a843, 2017-08-21T07:17:17.874Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.15063
- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
markdown-preview-github-styles|bie|0.0.2
path-intellisense|chr|1.4.2
ts-tslint|eg2|0.0.4
ejs|Sim|0.0.1
glslx-vscode|eva|0.0.11
easy-less|mrc|1.4.5
mssql|ms-|1.1.0
typescript-javascript-grammar|ms-|0.0.23
debugger-for-chrome|msj|3.1.8
vetur|oct|0.9.4
vscode-icons|rob|7.12.0
markdown-all-in-one|yzh|0.8.3



---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open `Keyboard Shortcuts`.
2. Search for `Trigger Suggest`.
3. Right click on `Trigger Suggest`, click `Show Conflicts`.

Expected Result:

The shortcuts list is filtered to only `Ctrl+Space` (`Trigger Suggest` and `toggleSuggestionDetails`).

Actual Result:

The list also includes `Delete Word Left` and `deleteWordLeft` which have the shortcut `Ctrl+Backspace`.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1330321/29594733-749bc984-87e5-11e7-813e-2c48f7547d5f.png)

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: WordWrapping is ON regardless of User Settings
data.body:
The problem is that files with lines over 10000 characters are wordWrapped regardless of the user setting.

Here is a file that demonstrates word wrapping being turned on regardless of settings:
[test_wrapping.txt](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/files/1243731/test_wrapping.txt)


Steps to Reproduce:

1. Ensure "editor.wordWrap": "off"
2. Fill up any single line up to column 10001.
3. Switch to a different file and then back.
4. The file will show wrapped text regardless of the editor.wordWrap setting.
Note: It's not just the long lines getting wrapped either. It appears to be turned on for the entire file. 


Reproduces without extensions: Yes, this was reproduced without extensions.

---

- VSCode Version: Code 1.15.1 (41abd21afdf7424c89319ee7cb0445cc6f376959, 2017-08-16T18:07:25.676Z)

data.title: File tab bar queues mouse middle clicks while modal dialog is active
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.15.1 (41abd21afdf7424c89319ee7cb0445cc6f376959, 2017-08-16T17:15:57.756Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 16.5.0
- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
python|don|0.7.0



---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open new Code window
2. Create one new document and add any content to it, without saving
3. Create another new document and also add any content to it
4. Middle-mouse-click either document. A modal dialog appears asking if you want to close without saving. Do not dismiss it.
5. Middle-mouse-click the other document while the modal dialog is visible.
6. Dismiss the modal dialog using "Don't save" or "Cancel" (save probably works too, but I haven't tried it).

Expected behavior: while the modal dialog is active, events to the blocked window are discarded. When the modal dialog is dismissed, the second document to be middle-clicked is still alive and well.

Actual result: immediately after the modal dialog is dismissed, another one appears asking what to do with the second document that was middle-clicked, confirming that events are queued instead of discarded. This seems to work with an arbitrary number of documents. I have not tested other interactions (like double-clicking the tab bar to create a new document).

Other UI elements, like the file panel of the left bar, are blocked.

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Probably? Don't think the Python extension impacts this.

VSCode fights fixing mismatched parens
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.15.1 (41abd21afdf7424c89319ee7cb0445cc6f376959, 2017-08-16T17:15:57.756Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 16.7.0
- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
vscode-generate-getter-setter|DSK|0.4.2
bazel-code|Dev|0.1.8
calculate|aca|1.1.1
path-intellisense|chr|1.4.2
vscode-svgviewer|css|1.4.2
vscode-eslint|dba|1.2.11
gitlens|eam|4.4.0
tslint|eg2|0.17.0
git-project-manager|fel|1.3.2
auto-rename-tag|for|0.0.14
docthis|joe|0.4.8
contextualduplicate|laf|0.2.0
debugger-for-chrome|msj|3.1.8
vscode-subword-navigation|ow|1.1.5
Align|ste|0.2.0
rewrap|stk|1.4.2
vscode-import-cost|wix|2.5.0
clang-format|xav|1.5.0
vscode-proto3|zxh|0.1.2

(3 theme extensions excluded)
---

## Steps to Reproduce:

Given this code:
```typescript
if ((([].includes()) {

}
```
put your cursor before one of the `)`s and hit the `)` key.

## Expected result
A `)` is inserted

## Actual result
VSCode moves the cursor to the right each time you hit `)`, but doesn't insert a paren until the cursor is at the end of the closing parens.

data.title: Linux: VS Code doesn't respect DISPLAY environment variable
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.14.2
- OS Version: Debian + Linux 4.9.30

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Launch vscode in an X session with DISPLAY=:0
2. Start a second X session on DISPLAY=:1
3. Try to launch vscode on the second X session

vscode does not open on DISPLAY=:1. Instead, the running instance on DISPLAY=:0 is raised/activated.

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes/No

data.title: On the latest public Windows Insider Fast Ring build (16257) VS Code can't open OneDrive files
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.15.1 (41abd21afdf7424c89319ee7cb0445cc6f376959, 2017-08-16T18:07:25.676Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.16257
- Extensions: none
---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Upgrade your PC to the latest available Windows 10 Insider Fast Ring build (16257)
2. The new OneDrive client has the option to let you see like if they're local also files that are on the cloud.
3. Try to maintain a local copy of a text file or a folder from OneDrive but right clicking on it and choosing "Always keep on this device"
4. Right click on it and choose "Edit with Code"
5. Notice that an empty file is opened
6. Manually open Code and try to open the same file from File -> Open file.
7. You'll see an error claiming that the file doesn't exist.

If you try to do the same with any other editor (like notepad) the file is properly opened.

data.title: UnhandledPromiseRejectionError when installing extensions
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.15.1
- OS Version: elementary OS 0.4.1 Loki

Steps to Reproduce:

1. `code --install-extension donjayamanne.python`

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes (I don't have any extensions installed.)

```
Found 'donjayamanne.python' in the marketplace.
Installing...
(node:3713) UnhandledPromiseRejectionWarning: Unhandled promise rejection (rejection id: 1): TypeError: this._state.then is not a function
(node:3713) DeprecationWarning: Unhandled promise rejections are deprecated. In the future, promise rejections that are not handled will terminate the Node.js process with a non-zero exit code.
```

I can't seem to install any extensions in VSCode. I've tried a number of them and none of them complete their installation, they just hang there.
